section.title: The Provider Networks Extension (provider)
section.para: The provider networks extension allows Quantum API users which are provided the appropriate rights, to specify mappings between a network object and the underlying networking infrastructure.
To this aim, it extends the network resource by defining a set of attributes preprendend by the, provider prefix, which specify these mappings.

section.title: Concepts
section.para: The provider networks extension is sn attribute extension, which adds the following set of attributes to the network resource:

listitem.para: provider:network_type - Specifies the nature of the physical network mapped to this network resource. Examples are FLAT, VLAN, or GRE;

provider:physical_network - Identifies the physical network on top of which this network object is being implemented. The Quantum API at the moment does not expose any facility for retrieving the list of available physical networks. As an example, in the Open vSwitch plugin this is a symbolic name which is then mapped to specific bridges on each compute host through the Open vSwitch agent's configuration file.

provider:segmentation_id - A mapping to a specific network segment according to the segmentation model defined by network_type. For instance, if network_type is VLAN, then this is a VLAN identifier; otherwise, if network_type is GRE, then this will be a GRE key.

section.para: The actual semantics of these attributes depend on the technology backend of the particular plugin. It is therefore advisable to refer to plugin document or to the Quantum administration guide in order to understand which values should be specific for each of these attributes when Quantum is deployed with a particular plugin. The examples shown in this chapter refer to the Open vSwitch plugin.

It is also worth noting that the default policy settings allow only users with administrative rights to specify these parameters in requests, and to see their values in responses. By default, the provider network extension attributes are completely hidden from regular tenants. As a rule of thumb, if these attributes are not visible in a GET /networks/<network-id> operation, this implies the user submitting the request is not authorized to view or manipulate provider network mappings.

section.title: Network API operations with provider network extension
section.para: This section discusses operations for setting and retrieving the provider extension attributes for network objects.

section.title: List Networks

tr.td: Returns a list of networks with their provider networks mappings.

section.para: Normal Response Code: 200 OK
Error Response Codes: 401 Unauthorized

When the provider networks extension is enabled, and the user submitting the request is authorized to see provider networks mapping, this operation returns, for each network, its provider network mappings, as well as all the attributes normally retuned by the list networks operation.

example.title: List Networks with provider mappings: JSON Response
List Networks with provider mappings: XML Response

section.title: Show Network

tr.td: Returns details about a specific network, including provider networks mappings.

section.para: Normal Response Code: 200 OK
Error Response Code: 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found

When the provider networks extension is enabled, and the user submitting the request is authorized to see provider networks mapping, this operation returns, for the network specified in the request URI, its provider network mappings, as well as all the attributes normally retuned by the list networks operation.

example.title: Show network with provider mappings: JSON Response
Show network with provider mappings: XML Response

section.title: Create Network

tr.td: Creates a new network and explicitly specify mappings with the underlying infrastructure using the provider network extension attributes.

section.para: Normal Response Code: 200 OK
Error Response Code: 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 403 Forbidden

When the provider networks extension is enabled, and the user submitting the request is authorized to set provider networks mapping, this operation allows for specifying how a new network should be mapped on the underlying network infrastructure.
If the user submitting the request is not allowed to set provider networks mappings, a 403 Forbidden response will be returned.

As stated earlier in this chaper, the semantics of the various provider networks attribute vary with the particular plugin employed. The following example shows how to create a network mapped to a specific VLAN tag (the example refers to a Quantum deployment which uses the Open vSwitch plugin).

section.title: Update Network

tr.td: Updates a network, including its mapping with the underlying instracture using the provider network extension attributes.

section.para: Normal Response Code: 200 OK
Error Response Code: 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 403 Forbidden

When the provider networks extension is enabled, and the user submitting the request is authorized to see provider networks mapping, this operation allows for specifying how an existing network should be mapped on the underlying network infrastructure.
If the user submitting the request is not allowed to set provider networks mappings, a 403 Forbidden response will be returned.

As stated earlier in this chaper, the semantics of the various provider networks attribute vary with the particular plugin employed. The following example shows how to update a network in order to map it to a specific VLAN tag (the example refers to a Quantum deployment which uses the Open vSwitch plugin).
